Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: The ambulance driver is on standby at the station, ready for any new dispatch to come in.
Story: I sat in the break room at the ambulance station, my phone in hand, staring at the message draft to my mentor. I had a question about a term in the training manual—nothing urgent, but I knew I was supposed to communicate any confusion right away. My mentor always emphasized that no concern was too small, and I wanted to show I was engaged and proactive. But as I started typing, the radio crackled, and my heart jumped. I was on standby, ready to respond to any emergency at a moment’s notice. Every second counted in this job, and I couldn’t risk being distracted or delayed if a call came in. I felt torn—should I send the message now, fulfilling my responsibility as a good mentee, or wait, staying laser-focused on my duty as an ambulance driver? The pressure of both roles pressed in on me, each demanding my full attention, and I sat frozen, phone in hand, caught between the expectations of two worlds.
